data.question: Can you provide practice problems on multiplying two matrices?

docs.title: 674dcdb4b00b977d048c931b
docs.text: The admission tickets to the Singapore Zoo are $50 for an adult, $36 for a child, and $20 for a senior citizen. On a particular Tuesday, there were 212 adults, 251 children, and 15 senior citizens who visited the Singapore Zoo and on a particular Wednesday, there were 231 adults, 266 children, and 12 senior citizens who visited the Singapore Zoo. The number of visitors on the particular Tuesday and Wednesday can be represented by the matrix V = \begin{pmatrix} 212 & 251 & 15 \\ 231 & 266 & 12 \end{pmatrix}. \text{ (i) Write a } 3 \times 1 \text{ matrix, P, to represent the price of the admission tickets. (ii) Find the matrix } T = VP. \text{ (iii) Explain what each of the elements represents. (iv) Find the total amount collected from the sales of the tickets for the 2 days.}

docs.title: 674dcde1b00b977d048c9352
docs.text: Two outlets of a coffee chain sell three different types of coffee: espresso, flat white and mocha. The table shows the number of cups of each type of coffee sold on a particular day. Outlet A: Espresso 30, Flat White 30, Mocha 35; Outlet B: Espresso x, Flat White x + 2, Mocha 40. This information can be represented by the matrix \( P = \begin{pmatrix} 30 & 30 & 35 \\ x & x+2 & 40 \end{pmatrix} \). The coffee chain sells a cup of espresso at $2.50, a cup of flat white at $4 and a cup of mocha at $5.50. This information can be represented by the matrix \( Q = \begin{pmatrix} 2.5 \\ 4 \\ 5.5 \end{pmatrix} \). (a) Find, in terms of x, the matrix \( R = PQ \).

docs.title: 674dce0fb00b977d048c9395
docs.text: (c) Evaluate the matrix G = LC.

docs.title: 674dce10b00b977d048c9397
docs.text: (e) The dance school wants to attract more students, so in the next 10-week block, the dance school reduces the price for cultural and international dance sessions by 10%. For this block of sessions, on weekdays, there are 5 cultural dance students and 12 international dance students. On weekends, there are 8 cultural dance students and 15 international dance students. By using matrix multiplication, calculate the total amount of money the dance school earns for this 10-week block of sessions.

docs.title: 674dce93b00b977d048c93d2
docs.text: On a particular week, supermarket A was offering a store-wide 20% discount promotion while supermarket B was offering a store-wide 10% discount promotion. Write down a matrix P, such that the product of P and T would give the discounted prices which Ron and Zoe each has to pay if they purchase the items from supermarkets A and B respectively.

docs.title: 674dce93b00b977d048c93d3

docs.title: 674dcd9fb00b977d048c9306
docs.text: Solve the simultaneous equations: \( 7x + 2y = 8 \) and \( 3x - y = 3 \).

docs.title: 674dce1ab00b977d048c93a4
docs.text: Jane exchanged 500 Singapore dollars ($) into Thai baht (THB) when the exchange rate was $1 = 26.77 THB. She travelled to Thailand and spent 10,600 THB. On her return to Singapore, she exchanged the remaining Thai baht into dollars with the exchange rate $1 = 26.88 THB. Calculate the amount she received in dollars. Correct your answer to the nearest cent.

data.output:
On a busy day at the amusement park, there are three types of visitors: adults, teenagers, and children. The number of these visitors for Saturday and Sunday is represented by the matrix:
\[ W = \begin{bmatrix} 120 & 130 & 110 \\ 150 & 140 & 100 \end{bmatrix} \]
The entrance fee for each type is $40 for an adult, $30 for a teenager, and $25 for a child. Representing this information as a matrix \( U \): 
\[ U = \begin{bmatrix} 40 \\ 30 \\ 25 \end{bmatrix} \]
Calculate the revenue matrix \( R = WU \).

A bookstore sells three types of items: books, notebooks, and pens. The table below shows the sales for two different stores over one week.

\[
\text{Store} \quad \text{Books} \quad \text{Notebooks} \quad \text{Pens} \\
A \quad 120 \quad 85 \quad 50 \\
B \quad y \quad y + 10 \quad 70 \\
\]

The sales data can be represented by the matrix \( S = \begin{bmatrix} 120 & 85 & 50 \\ y & y + 10 & 70 \end{bmatrix} \).

The prices for each item are represented by the matrix \( P = \begin{bmatrix} 15 \\ 7 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix} \).

(a) Calculate, in terms of \( y \), the total revenue matrix \( R = SP \).

(b) Explain what each element of matrix \( R \) represents.

(c) If Store B collected $85 more than Store A in revenue, find \( y \).

(d) State the total revenue for both stores combined.

A theme park has special admission tickets: $60 for an adult, $40 for a teenager, and $25 for a child. On a weekend, a group consisted of 180 adults, 227 teenagers, and 43 children on Saturday; and 190 adults, 210 teenagers, and 37 children on Sunday.

\[ V = \begin{bmatrix} 180 & 227 & 43 \\ 190 & 210 & 37 \end{bmatrix} \]

(i) Write a \( 3 \times 1 \) matrix, \( P \), that represents the price of admission tickets.

(ii) Find the matrix \( T = VP \).

(iii) Explain what each of the elements of matrix \( T \) represents.

(iv) Find the total amount collected from the sales of the tickets for the weekend.
